# 1. Company Overview (ODFL) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

Old Dominion Freight Line, Inc. is one of the largest North American less-than-truckload ("LTL") motor carriers and provides regional, inter-regional and national LTL services through a single integrated, union-free organization. Old Dominion Freight Line, Inc. operates as a less-than-truckload motor carrier in the United States and North America. Old Dominion Freight Line, Inc. was founded in 1934 and is headquartered in Thomasville, North Carolina.

Old Dominion Freight Line's primary revenue generation comes from its extensive less-than-truckload (LTL) shipping services. These services cover regional, inter-regional, and national transportation needs, forming the backbone of the company's financial performance. Old Dominion Freight Line (ODFL) is a major player in the less-than-truckload (LTL) freight sector, known for its operational strength. The company's business model centers on providing reliable and efficient LTL services. ODFL focuses on direct service, minimizing the need for interlining with other carriers, which enhances transit times and reduces the risk of damage or loss.

What sets Old Dominion Freight Line apart is its consistent delivery of premium service, a key component of its business model. This is evidenced by a 99% on-time service performance and a cargo claims ratio consistently below 0.1%. This dedication to reliability and minimal damage has earned the company the Mastio Quality Award for National LTL Carrier for 15 consecutive years as of 2024.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

In addition to its core LTL services, the company offers expedited, logistics and household moving services. The company has five primary product groups: Domestic, Expedited, People, Global, Household Services and Technology.

Global offerings include full container load (FCL) and less-than-container load (LCL) service to the Caribbean, Europe, the Far East, Central America and South America.

It also provides various value-added services, including container drayage, truckload brokerage, and supply chain consulting. In addition, the company operates service and fleet maintenance centers.

Beyond its main LTL offerings, Old Dominion Freight Line monetizes through 'Other Services.' This category includes expedited shipping, supply chain consulting, and truckload brokerage. Revenue from these ancillary services saw a 5.1% increase year-over-year in Q1 2025, reaching $14.02 million. For the full year 2024, other services contributed $53.7 million.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

The Company expects its aggregate capital expenditures for 2025 to total approximately $575 million, including planned expenditures of $300 million for real estate and service center expansion projects; $225 million for tractors and trailers; and $50 million for information technology and other assets.

OD will allocate $300 million toward land acquisition, new service centers, and facility upgrades. With an existing network of 261 service centers across the continental U.S., OD aims to enhance its infrastructure to improve shipping lanes and shorten transit times.

To date in 2024, we've opened four new service centers in our LTL network: a new facility in Green Bay, Wisconsin, to service eastern Wisconsin; a new breakbulk facility with 139 dock doors in Tannersville, Pennsylvania; a new service center along our southern border in Del Rio, Texas to improve our Mexico Direct Distribution service, help with cross docking freight going to and from Mexico, and building capacity in the area as we are seeing more manufacturing nearshoring activity; and a new and improved facility in Webster, Massachusetts to serve our customers in the greater Worcester area. These additions are part of our 2024 capital expenditure plan, which includes an allocation of approximately $350 million to purchase land and further expand the capacity of our service center network.

## 5. Growth Strategy

The company employs a disciplined yield management strategy, utilizing cost-based pricing to counteract inflation. Despite a 6.3% decrease in LTL tons per day in Q1 2025, Old Dominion Freight Line increased LTL revenue per hundredweight by 2.2%. This demonstrates strong pricing power, further boosted by attracting lighter, higher-rated shipments. The long-term strategy focuses on consistent yield improvements. These gains are reinvested into capacity expansion, technological advancements, and employee development programs. The company's approach to Old Dominion Freight Line operations is centered on maximizing revenue per shipment through strategic pricing and operational efficiency. This focus on yield management is a key component of the Growth Strategy of Old Dominion Freight Line, ensuring profitability even when shipment volumes fluctuate.

Old Dominion is sticking to its organic growth strategy. With conservative volume acceptance and excess capacity held in reserve, ODFL is prioritizing network quality and long-term efficiency.

We finished the first quarter of 2024 with approximately 30 percent excess capacity in our service center network. The excess capacity, while often costly to maintain, allows us to be ready for an increase in demand from our customers, so we're prepared to grow when you grow.

### Fleet and Infrastructure:
As of December 31, 2024, it owned and operated 11,284 tractors, 31,451 linehaul trailers, and 15,263 pickup and delivery trailers.

Old Dominion Freight Line operates an expansive network of 261 service centers across the United States. This extensive presence, supported by approximately $2.5 billion invested in its service center network over the past decade, underpins its significant capacity and market reach.

Management expects continued revenue and tonnage pressure into early 2026 unless macro conditions improve.

LTL carriers have continued to experience weakened freight volumes, especially in industrial segments impacted by higher interest rates and cautious manufacturing activity. As truckload (TL) rates remain low, some heavier shipments that might traditionally move via LTL have shifted into the TL market, reducing the average weight per shipment and leaving unfilled capacity in certain LTL networks.

### Tailwinds:
Industry capacity remains limited, presenting opportunities for market share growth as demand improves.

The LTL industry is experiencing a period of transition, with analysts suggesting that the freight cycle may have reached its bottom. While a robust recovery is not expected until the second quarter of 2025, there are indications of muted progress in the sector. The industry is poised to benefit from consolidation trends, near-shoring of manufacturing, and increasing demands from e-commerce deliveries.

FedEx Freight's planned spin-off into a standalone publicly traded company by 2026 stands as one of the most significant developments, with analysts projecting it could unlock up to $20 billion in market value. This move will likely intensify competition as the newly independent FedEx Freight pursues aggressive growth strategies, including hiring 300 additional sales professionals and implementing enhanced pricing systems.

The recent industry consolidation, particularly the impact of Yellow Corporation's exit, has created opportunities for carriers like Saia to expand their customer base and network reach.

## 9. Market Shares

ODFL remains in the #2 spot with 11.1% of the market. XPO comes in #3 with about an 8.9% share. Other publicly traded companies in the top 10 include #6 Saia and #7 ABF/Arc Best.

FedEx Freight leads with $8.901 billion in revenue, followed by Old Dominion at $5.815 billion. This dominance reflects both organic growth and market share gains following industry consolidation.

The total US LTL market size was $52.828 billion in 2024, with the top 25 carriers accounting for $48.175 billion (91% market share). This concentration enables the largest LTL carriers to invest heavily in network density, technology platforms, and service consistency that smaller competitors struggle to match.

Old Dominion is the second-largest less-than-truckload or LTL carrier in the United States, only behind FedEx Freight and ahead of Estes Express Lines, using 2024 revenues.

ODFL is consistently recognized for its superior quality, marked by high on-time delivery rates and exceptionally low claims ratios. This positions them as a premium service provider in the LTL market. As the largest LTL carrier by revenue, FedEx Freight offers extensive regional and national services supported by a vast network. Customer satisfaction surveys rank ODFL highest among national carriers for 16 consecutive years. Additionally, Old Dominion Freight Line is renowned for its low damage claims, further solidifying its reputation for reliability and quality.
